story.headline: Dhaka Sinks While the Seas Rise
story.summary: Dhaka, one of the world's most densely populated cities, faces a dual threat: annual monsoon flooding that submerges up to a third of Bangladesh, and accelerating sea level rise that threatens to permanently inundate low-lying coastal areas.
story.climateImpact: Sea level rise and intensified monsoons driven by climate change increase flooding frequency and severity, displacing millions and threatening food production in one of the world's most climate-vulnerable nations.
causeEffect: Global warming accelerates ice sheet melting and thermal expansion
Sea levels in the Bay of Bengal are rising 3-4 mm/year
Warmer atmosphere holds more moisture, intensifying monsoons
Monsoon flooding submerges 20-30% of Bangladesh annually
Saltwater intrusion ruins agricultural land and freshwater supplies
story.scaleContext: Bangladesh is home to 170 million people, with 30 million living in coastal zones less than 1 meter above sea level. By 2050, climate change could displace 13 million Bangladeshis internally.
story.outlook: Without massive investment in flood defenses, managed retreat, and global emissions reductions, Dhaka and coastal Bangladesh face catastrophic losses within decades.

title: Dhaka Sinks While the Seas Rise
summary: Dhaka faces annual monsoon flooding and accelerating sea level rise, with 30 million people living in zones less than 1m above sea level.
